The problem is that I'm struggling to test a pretty complex piece of
code and I'm trying to get some advice ( hints, help, etc .. ) to help
me tackle it.  

In the real world, I use ATG Dynamo.  If you've heard of it or used
it, it's an App Server / EJB Container.   Dynamo's entire framework is
based off this component known as Nucleus, which does a lot of work in
terms of instantiating classes, setting properties, etc..  It's also
very slow and to test - build - test takes forever if I have to start
and stop the app-server for every change in the code. 

That's where MockObjects come in.  Dynamo is a very Java Beans heavy
framework, that relies a lot on setters and getters.  ( In fact, the
MockObjects guys at SF have started putting together some Dynamo
MockObjects. ) I was looking into MockObjects as a way to lessen my
reliance on the Nucleus namespace so that I could code quickly and
only integrate with the Nucleus namespace at the latest possible time.

However, I can't get my head around the fact that in certain cases my
mock code will need to generate other mock code 

Here's a method from a piece of old code that I wrote before I decided
to start using JUnit:

    public  Map generateEmptyPreferencesMap( Map m ) throws
RepositoryException {

	// get the list of possible preferences
	RepositoryView contactMethodView = getPreferencesRepository().getView(
CONTACT_METHOD_REPOSITORY_ITEM );
	RepositoryItem[] contactMethods = contactMethodView.executeQuery(
contactMethodView.getQueryBuilder().createUnconstrainedQuery() );
	
	if ( ( contactMethods != null ) && ( contactMethods.length > 0 ) )  {
	    // add each one to the map
	    for ( int i = 0 ; i < contactMethods.length ; i++ ) {
		m.put( contactMethods[i].getPropertyValue(
CONTACT_METHOD_CODE_PROPERTY_NAME ), new BooleanPlaceHolder() );
	    }
	}
     return m;
    }
     

The Repository API is Dynamo's object-oriented data abstraction api. 
In this case, I assume I would setPreferencesRepository( new
MyMockRepository()  )

but that MockRepository needs to return a MockRepositoryView which in
turn needs to return a MockQueryBuilder, or so I seem to believe.

In a sentence:  how would one test this?  

As before,
Any and all help is greatly appreciated.

I apologize for any unnecessary lengthiness.

Thanks,

Aadi

--- In junit@y..., Bob Koss <koss@o...> wrote:
> 
> It would help if you'd tell us what the problem is instead of presenting
> your solution of the problem as the problem.
> 
> I've never needed mocks inside of mocks - it doesn't even make sense.
> 
>
